description:
(2016) Brett Dennen - Por Favor



Review:
Since making his debut in 2004, Brett Dennenâ€˜s amiable folk-pop has earned him a loyal following and placed him among some of the previous decadeâ€™s more prominent contemporary pop troubadours, from Jason Mraz to Ray LaMontagne.
While he hasnâ€™t quite enjoyed the success of those acts, itâ€™s certainly not for lack of trying. His wealth of hooky melodies and thoughtful acoustic musings has been spread out over five strong releases and his almost John Denver-like aura of sincerity gives him an approachable allure. On Por Favor, the singerâ€™s sixth effort, he strips his music down to the barest essentials to create what is easily his most vulnerable and intimate album. Admittedly worn thin by a relationship on the rocks, family trouble, and a health scare, this is a Dennen weâ€™ve never heard, with a noticeably frayed spirit and a searching heart. The feeling of heightened sensitivity and the minimalist production from Nashvilleâ€™s Dave Cobb (Sturgill Simpson, Jason Isbell) gives Por Favor more of an organic and timeless feeling than any of Dennenâ€™s prior work, and his quavering high tenor has never sounded so appropriate to the material. But even in his darkest hours, Dennenâ€™s breezy style and humble demeanor make him come off like a fallen optimist trying to retune his antenna sunward. Light tones of calypso and reggae color tracks like â€œWhatâ€™s the Secret?â€ and â€œStand Up for It,â€ and the rhythm section of drummer Chris Powell and bassist Brian Allen pepper the tunes with a roomy, off-the-cuff vibe. On his sunnier moments, Dennen evokes the loose, rootsy vibe of American Beauty-era Grateful Dead, and thereâ€™s even a reference to Jerry Garcia on the hushed standout â€œStrawberry Road.â€ Recorded in just a couple of weeks at Cobbâ€™s all-analog Nashville studio, the performances are loose and honest, with tape hiss filling the gaps between chords on quieter tunes like â€œWhere We Left Offâ€ and the bittersweet closer â€œIâ€™ll Be on Your Side.â€ As both a writer and a singer, Dennen has never sounded so fragile and unpolished and itâ€™s a perfect fit for this fantastic group of songs.
